metadata.sermon_title: The Voice of the Son of Man
metadata.sermon_start_end: If you know your Christian calendar, you’re getting goose bumps. There is a great shift in the lectionary that begins after All Saints’ Day. Last Sunday was a good example. The readings from Scripture start getting apocalyptic in November. This coming Sunday is the last Sunday of the Christian year [...] that in the last day, when he shall come again in his glorious majesty to judge both the living and the dead, we may rise to the life immortal; through him who liveth and reigneth with thee and the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on a single specific pericope. It drifts between Mark 13, John 16, John 5, and general liturgical themes. It treats 'apocalyptic' as a general biblical idea rather than unearthing what Mark 13 specifically says that cannot be found elsewhere. It becomes a speech about a theme (the end times) rather than an exposition of a text.
quotes: The lessons are concerned with the great themes of the end of all things
The Gospel for this week, Mark 13, speaks of...
One part of Mark 13 that jumps out at me is...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Restrict the sermon to Mark 13. Identify the unique logic of this specific chapter—such as the specific relationship between the destruction of the Temple and the parousia—rather than merging it with Johannine theology.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a brief mention of the Greek word 'thlipsis', but the original historical context of Mark's community (the Jewish War, the destruction of the Temple) is largely ignored in favor of modern parallels like the Holocaust or nuclear war. The 'exposition' is more of a thematic summary.
quotes: “Tribulation” (thlipsis in Greek) is a word that the New Testament uses to describe the signs of the coming kingdom.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the historical-critical work. Explain what the 'abomination of desolation' meant for the first readers to ground the 'thlipsis' in concrete history before moving to contemporary application.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in parts (mentioning New York City, small groups, and personal safety), which Dekker requires. However, it often retreats into generalities about 'hope' and 'confidence' which lack the 'sharpness' of the apocalyptic text.
quotes: now in our own lives in the city of New York in a time of uneasy discontent
recently I went out and bought a little purse with a cross-body strap that might foil a thief
Have you ever thought of your small group... as a sign of the coming kingdom of God?
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'tribulation' more sharply to specific contemporary 'misery'. The purse anecdote is a start, but the application to 'small groups' feels somewhat disconnected from the cosmic gravity of the text.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat traditional 'block' structure: liturgical context, then biblical theme, then contemporary relevance, then back to the 'voice' of Jesus. The hearer is not consistently 'drawn into the text' as a single movement; the text often serves as a springboard for the preacher's reflections.
quotes: And, as always, the big question is, What has it all got to do with us, personally?
Now here is the part of the story that has to do with you and me
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid phrases like 'Now here is the part... that has to do with you.' Instead, let the exposition of the text itself be the application by showing how the text 'expounds' the hearer's current reality.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly addresses 'misery' (tribulation, evil, suffering) and 'redemption' (the coming King). It avoids a purely objective Christocentrism by focusing on the human experience of 'uneasy discontent' and the need for 'courage'.
quotes: Suffering and distress are inescapable in a world fallen away from God.
The Christian life is not a pleasure trip and never was.
God is accomplishing his purposes in spite of all appearances to the contrary.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure 'gratitude' (the third part) is more clearly linked to the Spirit's work in the present, rather than just a future hope.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon touches on the 'two ways' by mentioning the 'ruler of this world' and the 'last judgment,' but it softens the blow. The 'lostness' is more of a 'mood of dark uncertainty' than a radical choice between life and destruction.
quotes: “We believe that he will come to be our Judge.” That means that the destiny of the whole world is in the hands of a Savior...
the broad way that leads to destruction [implied by 'reign of Death']
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'seriousness of choice' more directly. If there is a judgment, what is the 'broad way' for a New Yorker today? Make the 'temporal loss' more explicit.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes the 'voice of the Son of God' as the ultimate authority and source of life. It maintains the 'two natures' by speaking of the itinerant preacher who is also the cosmic Lord.
quotes: The one Lord who is central in the sermon is Christ.
The voice of Jesus is not like any other voice ever heard... a voice of authority, cosmic, universal authority.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Connect the 'grace' more specifically to the 'misery' identified. How does the 'Son of Man' specifically redeem the 'uneasy discontent' of the city?

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely clocks in just under the 20-minute threshold (approx. 18-19 minutes). According to Dekker, it lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition of the specific Bible passage to reach the 20-minute mark, allowing the text more room to breathe before moving to application.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a thematic reflection on 'Apocalyptic' and 'Advent' than a strict exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks the textual specificity Dekker demands, frequently jumping between different biblical books to support a general theological idea. While it successfully engages with the 'misery' of the modern world and correctly identifies Christ as the telos, it fails the formal requirement of being an actualization of *one* specific pericope.
strengths: Strong emphasis on the 'misery' of the fallen world, avoiding superficial optimism.
Clear Christological focus, presenting Christ as the cosmic Judge and Savior.
Concrete contemporary references (New York City, safety concerns) that ground the theology.
weaknesses: Lack of textual focus; the sermon is a topical speech rather than a pericope-based sermon.
Insufficient length (< 20 min) according to the Miskotte/Dekker standard.
Exegesis is subordinated to thematic synthesis, losing the 'unique' word of the specific text.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about the gospel' rather than a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker’s first thesis. It is theologically sound but homiletically diffuse. To become a sermon, it must submit itself to the discipline of a single text.
